pr_title: CorfuQueue: Capture commit token & fix up Queue for ordering

timeline.message:
CorfuQueue: preCommitCallbacks to capture txn address

The Queue needs to capture the exact address its entries were
written to, so it can then order its entries, of its orderless
hashmap (corfuTable), in the same order that its transactions
materialized.

To do this register a preCommitCallback that intercepts the
Sequencer's blessed tokenResponse and fills it up into
the payload of the fields of the Queue.

+ Randomize sleep in test case to catch out of order reliably.

CorfuQueue: preCommitCallbacks to capture txn address

The Queue needs to capture the exact address its entries were
written to, so it can then order its entries, of its orderless
hashmap (corfuTable), in the same order that its transactions
materialized.

To do this register a preCommitCallback that intercepts the
Sequencer's blessed tokenResponse and fills it up into
the payload of the fields of the Queue.

+ Randomize sleep in test case to catch out of order reliably.

timeline.bodyText: is it possible to get rid of setters?
timeline.author: xnull

replies.bodyText: no, it breaks SMR if we create a new object - we must modify the exact value that was added to the table's hash map.
replies.author: hisundar

replies.bodyText:
not sure about SMR, but if you are going to change these fields and use them to calculate hashCode then it is very dangerous operation you can break HashMap by that.
I mean if you change those fields after you add it to any java data structure like HashMap, Queue and so on, you will not be able to find that entry in the data structure
replies.author: xnull

timeline.bodyText: When you implement equals method you have to implement a hashCode method, if not then functionality will be broken.
timeline.author: xnull

timeline.bodyText: Also, please add @Owerride
timeline.author: xnull

timeline.bodyText: You must be very careful with setters. They always bring much more complexity to the code, make it fragile, more complicated to analyze and there are always problems with concurrency.
timeline.author: xnull

replies.bodyText: yes unfortunately we do not have access to the commit sequence and epoch until the transaction actually commits, so we cannot go with immutable construct. It has to be set later, creating a new copy would break it away from the SMR version.
replies.author: hisundar

replies.bodyText: sad to hear that we can't afford immutability, so, ok
replies.author: xnull

timeline.bodyText: why not to pass CorfuRecordId as a parameter?
timeline.author: xnull

replies.bodyText: because these fields need to be accessed and set individually at different times I thought it would be cleaner to separate those two.
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: Please don't use TransactionalContext as a prefix. Please add TransactionalContext to imports
timeline.author: xnull
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -248,6 +250,17 @@ public void syncWithRetryUnsafe(VersionLockedObject vlo,
      */
     public abstract void addTransaction(AbstractTransactionalContext tc);
 
+    /**
+     * Add an object that needs extra processing right before commit happens
+     *
+     * @param preCommitListener The context of the object that needs extra processing
+     *                         along with its lambda.
+     */
+    public abstract void addPreCommitListener(TransactionalContext.PreCommitListener preCommitListener);
+
+    @Getter
+    private List<TransactionalContext.PreCommitListener> preCommitListeners = new ArrayList<>();

timeline.bodyText: please add TransactionalContext to imports
timeline.author: xnull

timeline.message: Add test case for both inorder and our of order between enqueue op and txEnd.

timeline.bodyText: Actually instead of bolierplate code you should use @EqualsAndHashCode annotation from lombok. Can you make that change?
timeline.author: xnull

timeline.message: Add test case for both inorder and our of order between enqueue op and txEnd.

timeline.bodyText: Is it better to use invalid epoch and sequence instead of 0 ?
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

replies.bodyText: would it matter? keeping it as zero allows these non-transactional entries to go to the first of the queue - might make it easier for testing
replies.author: hisundar

replies.bodyText: But then if you compare the a non-tranactional entry with a tranactional entry who was committed at epoch 0, sequence 0,  it would be confusing right?
replies.author: WenbinZhu

replies.bodyText: yes, that isn't supported. ok let me catch that case and assert.
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: Private
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: Private
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: ordering -> sequence ?
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: Fix Indent
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: You can put a .limit(maxEntries) after .filter() to avoid collecting and sorting all entries and ++index. This should be more efficient.
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: Is it better to use invalid epoch and sequence instead of 0 ? Same for the rests
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

timeline.bodyText: I'm wondering if this is correct in case of nested transactions. In that case we would merge the read/write set in the child transaction's context into parent's context, however the preCommitListeners seems not doing this.
timeline.author: WenbinZhu
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -248,6 +251,17 @@ public void syncWithRetryUnsafe(VersionLockedObject vlo,
      */
     public abstract void addTransaction(AbstractTransactionalContext tc);
 
+    /**
+     * Add an object that needs extra processing right before commit happens
+     *
+     * @param preCommitListener The context of the object that needs extra processing
+     *                         along with its lambda.
+     */
+    public abstract void addPreCommitListener(PreCommitListener preCommitListener);

replies.bodyText: I thought about this - that is the reason I always pick the RootContext to store these preCommitListeners. As you said nesting transactions will keep merging their writeSets() anyway which is is unnecessary because only the address of the parent transaction matters anyway.
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: update method java doc, no returned value.
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: Can we have these two values '0', as statics with suggestive names that ease readability? Also, why do we enforce epoch to be 0? would it be better to have negative which means non-initialized?
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: Add class description?
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: perhaps add a trace level logging line here?
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: Can we add a comment making clear that enqueue's occurring outside the transactional scope will not be guaranteed ordering.
timeline.author: annym

replies.bodyText: not just that, I am enforcing it via an explicit check.
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: If the copy is after the comparison, wouldn't it skip one. For instance maxEntries =1, on the first entry it would immediately break and not add the single entry. Or change to index++
timeline.author: annym

replies.bodyText: I think your comment is on old version of the code - the whole loop is fixed up based on a previous comment, so I guess it can't happen anymore?
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: can we do the same, declare statics so it is easy to follow this init..
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: add trace or debug logging?
timeline.author: annym

timeline.bodyText: add some logging?
timeline.author: annym

The Queue needs to capture the exact address its entries were

timeline.bodyText: Looks like you are still using 0, 0 for non-transactional entries (the else branch in enqueue) ?
timeline.author: WenbinZhu

replies.bodyText: exactly, Queue is still usable if all enqueue() are non-transactional (unit tests only at this point)
replies.author: hisundar

replies.bodyText: I mean if we still use 0, 0 for non-transactional entries, we won't have entries with Address.NON_ADDRESS, so why do we need this check?
replies.author: WenbinZhu

replies.bodyText: yes I removed the check as you suggested.
replies.author: hisundar

Please fix
log.debug("ENQ: {} => {} at {}", i, queueData, streamOffset);

timeline.bodyText: We should remove the lock and generated some tx abort scenarios. You can define validator as a hashtable instead of an array. I am not clear if tx aborted, if the record will be removed from the queue or not?
timeline.author: xiaoqin2012

replies.bodyText: Aborts are definitely happening because we conflict on one of two values, for example in a test with 2000 transactions only about 1500 succeed. But I will add an assert to verify this too.
replies.author: hisundar

replies.bodyText: Actually it turns out travis sometimes serializes the runs which means there might not be any aborts due to concurrency. So I can't add an assert or test will become very non-deterministic :(
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: are snapshot transactions considered read-only?
timeline.author: pankti-m

replies.bodyText: yes, there are similar exceptions for attempting to write in a snapshot transaction
replies.author: hisundar

timeline.bodyText: Shouldnt it be overridden in WriteAfterWriteTransactionalContext as well?
timeline.author: pankti-m
